review_title: Was a great place to work, but the good times appear to be over
pros: Prior to COVID, they offered their employees great benefits. Many of them were still maintained during/after COVID, but quite a few were taken away or reduced. Still, in general, they do a great job of making you appreciate them. It can make it hard to know when it’s probably time to leave.
cons: The time of bread and circuses is coming to an end for Meta. Like many tech companies, Meta used crazy perks and benefits to help hide the duller parts of the work that folks have to perform. There’s nothing wrong with that, as I believe that it is a company’s prerogative to do what they can to entice employees to stay. But I’d often wondered when that would all be forced to stop due to declining revenue, and a flooding market due to those who believed a tech career was a sure fire way to get a six-figure salary right out of college. Well, it looks like that time is finally here. Many layoffs are alleged to have begun, while employee moral is in decline due to reduced benefits and a dramatically underperforming stock price. While there are still many good roles and fine people that work there, it appears that the company as a whole is heading into a rather rough patch.

job_title: Software Engineering Manager in London, England
pros: Great people around. The best I've ever met! Super ambitious goals. Great benefits. WFH flexibility.
cons:
Performance review. It works this way:

1. Leadership escalate project X
2. You clearly don't see any impact of X, but has to disagree and commit
3. You give the project to an eng from your team (even if they disagree)
4. Eng executes the project
5. PSC comes. And eng does not receive credit for X because, guess what, no impact

And this loop happens again and again. You build a special skill how to dodge from this crappy non impactful projects.

job_title: Senior Recruiter in San Francisco, CA
pros: What brought me here was the brand, what keeps me here are the challenges we face and the talented and fabulous people that I get to work with and learn from. In the two years that I have been here I have learned more than what I have learned in my entire career. I have learned from how others process information and look things, their approach to solving problems, how they structure information and the flags they raise. I have been able to see 'in action' different perspective that have brought awareness and growth, personally and professionally. The people I work with, is the number one reason I am still, and will continue to work here. A second important factor is the flexibility and multiple options that employees are given for returning to work post-pandemic. We have the ability to request remote work and relocate. Every employee has the option to tailor their work schedules and adopt to suite their life styles. Fair and competitive compensation and benefits are secondary.
cons: Every workplace has opportunities for growth and while not everything is perfect at Meta, no one has said that we have stopped growing. The constant changes indicate the pains of growth and bring hope that things are being looked at and that feedback from employees is being applied. My advise to those who flag issues and are passionate about specific changes is to stick around, work internally and drive change. Don't leave, work and make a change!

review_title: Great benefits, salary and growth opportunities
pros:
-The benefits can't be beat: Meta has excellent health insurance, child care assistance, family care assistance (elderly parents), pet care assistance, mat/pat leave, as well as a whole plethora of amazing benefits (pay for things like laundry, internet for remote employees, IVF, tax consultants, legal consultants, and the list goes on)
-The i18n team is really fabulous. I have never worked in such a supportive environment where I felt I could continuously learn and grow. SO MANY talented people from so many diverse backgrounds 
-The salary is really top notch. I interviewed with multiple other companies and had 2 competing offers and Meta's was the best base salary offer (you also get RSU/stocks and a bonus percentage)
-Internal mobility is great which opens up a lot of career/growth tracks
-My work impacts millions of people around the world, you can trace your work to impact and really change lives and that's exciting
-Work/life balance: this is my first job in i18n that I can clock off after 5pm and not feel pressured to work after hours or on weekends. It is really life changing. I don't know if this is the case for ALL LPMs, but it most definitely is for my pod/team.
cons:
-In such a large company, teams can feel siloed. This sometimes leads to work duplication and does not always optimize my time/efforts/expertise. This is a common problem I have seen in other companies as well
-Meta builds all of their internal tools (so for i18n this means our own TMS, CAT tools, but also our own ticketing/tracking system, internal comms systems etc). This is clunky and sometimes feels like we are really far behind tooling wise (and sometimes makes my job harder)
-Overall, not a lot of complaints!

review_title: Ignore polarized reviews, your experience will be distinctively average
pros:
- Packed with very smart people (often underutilized)
- Good pay and outstanding benefits
- For a big corporation, remarkable tolerance for internal dissent. People create open (everyone can read) groups where they poke fun at the idiosyncrasies of the company, and don't get fired for it.
- Internal tools are actually getting better despite being a bit rough around the edges
- Diversity: people don't look all the same (which is great)
- QA sessions with Zuckerberg are actually quite entertaining
- I was never insulted or attacked, and while I am sure it happened to someone, it is not customary: you are required to conduct yourself in a dignified way (which is great)
cons:
- There is relative freedom to choose teams (during bootcamp) and projects (during planning), but most projects/teams are pointless and/or dull, and people always seem to be doing A as a stopgap while they wait to move into B
- Not many options in London except AR/VR which is becoming difficult to get into (I mean, you don't want to work on Workplace, do you?)
- People are constantly looking for "impact", which means moving an arid and unimaginative metric someone else has defined. It's a crushingly sad show of very smart and insightful individuals running around begging for leftover projects that may move some metric by that 0.05% which will let them keep their job for another semester.
- Nobody knows how things work. When you ask why something is done in a certain way, it's likely the person originally responsible for it has just joined (and doesn't know anything and is just doing things at random) or has left or is about to leave (so he/she is not incentivized to help).
- Largely oral and office-based culture struggling to get into the habit of writing things down to communicate, after work got hybrid and teams became intercontinental

review_title: Largest waste of resources ever created
pros:
Highly talented people, many of who are motivated to do the right thing
Lots of resources available
Very high pay
cons:
It's a really large waste of talent due to:
-Lack of leadership development 
-Lack of proper performance management - it's all about results only and very high bonuses are awarded for results, without regard for values or ethics
All this together leads to a situation where all those highly talented people, motivated to do the right thing (improve Meta) are not able to fulfill their personal missions. Because the pay is so high, they stay and they become cynical and just do their job, becoming part of the system that does harm to society and individuals and give up on their original mission to make Meta better. Or they leave or get fired.

It's also a waste of time for the users.

Lastly it's a waste of advertising dollars from the micro and small businesses making up a very long tail and a very large share of income for Meta. Most of those advertising dollars not likely will have a positive ROI.

review_title: Total Chaos (not in a good way)
job_title: Sr Program Manager in Menlo Park, CA
pros:
Salary and benefits were great — though salary is not that great any more with the stock down $200/share.

Some really great people who want to make the platform better and safer for the users.
cons:
So many people doing the same work across the company but since it’s a bottoms up culture no one is reigning in the chaos. Meta could do with A LOT less staff if they had any real leadership that required people to align and remove duplicative work.

Your work is thrashed all the time because of lack of leadership and strategic thinking/planning. If you are lucky, half of what you do will make it to the finish line. This is a huge concern when going for your annual review because you are calibrated with others and depending on how your manager sells your work (or doesn’t) will really affect your career and progression.

Most executives still prioritize “giving people voice” over addressing platform concerns and the negative impacts that the platforms can cause. They need to take issues more seriously.

There are A LOT of bad managers that can derail your career. Going to HR is useless because they are there to support the manager and limit risk to Meta. I can’t tell you how many people I worked with that took paid mental health leave because of their bad manager. If you get a bad manager get out the team ASAP because it will take them at least 12 months to work them out once they have enough complaints and that is long enough for them to destroy your career.

There is no way for you to dispute your review. Some of my colleagues received a poor review from their manager but the review included inaccurate or false information (they had documentation to prove it), but there is no formal process to dispute your review. A bad review could cost you your career or make it difficult for you to switch teams.

Leadership is leaving left and right which should raise some red flags. Metaverse is a big bet that will take years to pay off (if at all). How many people want to live in a virtual world? No thanks, I prefer to live in reality. Yes, there are benefits like training surgeons to do surgery before they touch a human but has anyone heard Mark mention using the metaverse that way?

Product managers are incentivized to get the products out the door, not to do the right thing.

review_title: Onboarding Experience might be off  for Full-time remote employees

- The best tool to enable you to be productive and quickly work on what you need to do.
- Being around smart, kind, and intelligent people makes me learn and challenge. I enjoy working with these people.
- Great benefits and compensation
cons:
The onboarding experience was a bit off.
- Onboarding experience as a Full-time remote employee was not pleasant. The logistics did not work well. There were too many new remote employees like me, but not enough roles opened on different teams. I received two contradicting messages 1) I could take my time as I want 2) find the team as soon as possible.
- I think this depends on the team you get in. My current manager does not care about me. He wants me to work on something impactful on my roadmap within a short period since I started. I did not even have a reasonable chance to assess my team, work areas, and business partners.
- Above two bullets might get better over time. People work hard to improve their processes and try to assess the experience. So my rating is just about what I have been through in the current situation. I believe onsite employee's experience might be different.

Code quality tends to be poor. To be fair the product isn't exactly critical to the day to day operations of the world and FB being down for a few hours isn't going to kill anyone. Teams focus on getting products out as quickly as possible with little concern for quality or maintainability. There is no QA department and you will not be rewarded for taking extra time to make your project high quality

review_title: Avoid the Business Product Strategy team
pros: The ERGs are fun to participate in.
cons:
Avoid the business product strategy team at all costs! The team mandate is unclear, managers are inexperienced and micromanaging, performance is highly subjective, and morale is very low. The culture is transactional and output-oriented with a air of uncaring towards team members stemming from the most senior leadership. Constant reorgs make life hectic and attrition in the ABP org is high. The company is overall also cutting down on benefits and gearing towards cost savings, and the value of RSUs is way down. The metaverse bet is taking up a ton of resources and energy distracting from our core product lines, even while true metaverse products are about a decade out. Colleagues are more concerned about promotions and ladder climbing than they are about building great products for users, and overall the company feels extremely immature internally.

Salaries overall are low compared to market.

review_title: Great opportunity to work on cool products with smart people, difficult to move internally
pros:
Amazing place to learn and grow (trains you very well in leadership, data driven decision making, industry best practices, technical knowledge)
The people are generally very smart and creative, there can be a lot of grass roots problem solving and collaboration which can be very fun and energising
There are very smart people to learn from, with a strong management and mentoring culture which means it's easy to find strong sponsors and mentors who are genuinely invested in your growth
The perks and compensation are great, it's a difficult place to leave
The culture is highly transparent and logic driven, there is a genuine desire to do the right thing under highly complex circumstances where the trade offs are immense. People aren't afraid to challenge and there's often healthy discussion
cons:
Highly optimised for individual impact, which can be very empowering but also lead to some bias towards short term thinking (which the company is addressing)
Priorities shift very quickly which means vision, strategy and org structure are constantly evolving and changing. It's a wild ride which teaches you a lot but can be difficult when driven by a mission for it to be ever changing
Product Operations department has some very strong people and is a great place to learn due to variety, high expectations and need to lead and influence to be successful, however progression is not guaranteed and can feel challenging to reach the common career progression milestones (e.g. promotions). The combination of a low ceiling and many talented people means it's highly competitive
It can be challenging to move internally from operations to tech due to many bureaucratic  barriers that don't feel well aligned with ability and experience of the individual

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Menlo Park, CA
pros: Great people whom really care and want to make a difference. Great perks, total compensation is top of market. You get to leverage your expertise daily. You don't have to prove you're smart once you join - they trust in the hiring the right people. The company moves fast and is nimble. Very high growth. Work is challenging, and you get lots of opportunities to stretch and grow.
cons: COVID has made it almost untenable at Meta. Coverage for leaves falls on existing team with little to no empathy or support.  You're expected to just make it work and figure it out. There are no tradeoffs or prioritization with goals. Because nothing drops off the laundry list of priorities, few things actually get accomplished and the cycle repeats year after year. Meta is turning into a corporate behemoth that's too insular to accept and act on feedback from users, employees, etc... When you start to think you know best, and everyone else is just wrong, it's a bad sign (this isn't just a bad press cycle - Meta needs to get better about the negative role it plays in misinformation, harmful content, etc.)

pros: Amazing work-life balance. Working on cutting edge challenges that will define the next era of computing.
cons: Can sometimes be difficult to navigate given the size of the company. Re-orgs have been happening more often recently.

pros:
• Great people. Humble, collaborative, and passionate. Just working alongside my colleagues brings me joy

• Autonomy. Fb gives employees the freedom to make impact with very few (if any) bureaucratic guardrails. They trust their employees to make impact, so if I feel passionate about something I do it -- instead of first having to ask permission like I've been used to. 

• Diversity & Inclusion. FB doesn't just talk about the importance of DEI, they put the resources in place to actually make it happen. They have clear goals for the company to achieve diversity across the board (including within Leadership) and the provide proactive updates for how we're tracking. 

• Perks. The legends are true, but after more than a year still finding out about new benefits. Wellness award is my favorite and can be used to reimburse expenses for whatever helps you recover -- whether it's Spa Days, Ski Trips, or even an Apple Watch for tracking fitness.

• Career Growth. With the hyper growth opportunities for professional growth are abundant. 

• Too many others to include, but wanted to highlight some of the things beyond the normal 'glitz' you hear about (#Freefood #FacebookForty)
cons:
• Fast-paced, constant changes. While I personally love this about FB, I recognize there's a 'comfort' in knowing how your systems will operate day-to-day / week-to-week. With innovation there will be some misses, and if you don't have patience you will get frustrated.

• With the fast pace, you need to be proactive to expect career growth.

pros:
-Great benefits.
-Depending on team and manager, can have a lot of flexibility.
-Decent pay.
-Access to smart people you can learn from.
-Free therapy (you’ll need it).
cons:
-You’re expected to put on a show and constantly be self-promotional. Imagine it as if being a social influencer is a requirement of your job. 
-A lot of words about support and empathy without any real action. 
-Insanely volatile stock. 
-Depending on team, OGs might not be very open to n00bs and not help onboard. Seem to intentionally speak in acronyms to alienate new people.
-Many PMMs have a condescending, disdainful attitude towards Content.
-Constant, intense pressure to perform in an individualistic way. If you’ve previous adopted the POV that you can put your head down and just produce great work in order to be recognized and rewarded, you’ll be sad to learn that doesn’t work here. You must constantly toot your own horn, which can feel icky. 
-This leads to people doing things just for the sake of being able to say they did them. For example, publishing a playbook that’s already been created and shared by 4 other people, too.
-They say during onboarding that it takes 6 months to ramp up. In reality, you’re not given that. Managers start saying people are not performing if they’re not making showy presentations after 2-3 months. 
-No process at all. Autonomy is great, but it is downright chaos theory on a daily basis here. No timelines, due dates, no project management, no consistent tools used. Every team operates however they want, using whatever they want. Makes it very hard to collaborate across teams.

job_title: Senior Product Designer in Menlo Park, CA
pros:
General Pros:
The salary, the benefits, the prestige, the overall digital resources, and access to all sorts of groups. Some great people.

Product Design Pros:
Robust design systems, design expertise/protocols, and many new inspriring ways of working

There are some of the most amazing women there and some very good humans. Key word is some though.
cons:
Where can I start...the list is mega long. Should I start with the horrible recruitmentli/team placement mistake that caused major setback after setback. Yes, they put me on the type of team that they swore they never would. The really bad manager accountability, who prefers to be more of a boss vs. a leader. Or could I address some of the most ruthless and two-faced narcisstic coworkers with the most severe case of unconscious bias and fat egos you will ever encounter? Or is it really their fault or the company culture that made them that way? 

Its kind of like Squid games, but then you remember that the people you work with don't actually come from the most desperate lives who need to be fighting for their lives, just people with severe personality disorders/power trip and ego issues. I've talked to several designers on my team who were not happy, severely stressed, and felt super disparaged.
